However, following my strategy, voting for Player 6 seems to be a step towards uncovering potential threats as their behavior could be interpreted as slightly suspect.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 5 heals player 4. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 4. My reason is that according to my original strategy, especially rules [1], [4], and [9], protecting a confirmed seer is a top priority. Given that I have high confidence in Player 4\'s role as the seer and their alignment with the village, healing them ensures that their valuable insights continue to aid the village. Additionally, if the werewolves target Player 4 thinking they are unprotected, my action will not only save a key figure but also confirm my role, thereby potentially increasing the chances of villagers\' survival. This aligns with strategy [1], which suggests prioritizing the seer\'s protection, especially when they are at risk or targeted by werewolves, which is highly likely at this stage. If Player 4\'s claims as a seer are truthful, protecting them is critical for the village\'s success in identifying the werewolves.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Fellow villagers, the night was peaceful, which is a welcome change. Let\'s use this day to shore up our defenses and make sure that when the werewolves strike again, we are prepared. I urge everyone to stay observant. Together, we will protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'Fellow citizens, given the calm night, I stress the importance of vigilance. My visions confirm Player 0 as a villager and Player 5\'s medic role. Alas, my insights suggest Player 6 harbors deceit. They positioned themselves among the questionable, a potential tactic for a werewolf to dilute our focus. I must challenge Player 6 openly; our vigilance necessitates a thorough examination of their actions and words for the safety of our village.\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed by seer (Player 4).\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Neutral, non-substantial statement.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is seer with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information; previous high confidence.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Accused by seer (Player 4) and inconsistent behavior.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If there is a dispute about a player\'s role where the seer is involved, I should observe the behavior and voting patterns of both the accused player and the seer before deciding whom to protect or whom to vote against.] [10]\n[1] [If a player is confirmed as a seer by their actions and their role is publicly known, I should protect them, especially if their life is at risk or they have been targeted by werewolves.] [9]\n[2] [If a player\'s contributions during discussions are valuable and suspect defensive behavior is absent, I should consider them as a priority for protection.] [9]\n[3] [If a player is suspected by a group consensus based on reasonable evidence or a credible seer\'s claim, I should consider this in my voting and protection decisions.] [8]\n[4] [If a player\'s role is confirmed as a non-werewolf by the seer and they are actively contributing to village discussions, I should consider them for protection.] [7]\n[5] [If a villager\'s role is proven and they are contributing significantly to the village\'s strategy, I should consider direct or indirect methods to suggest the presence of a protective role like a medic, which can include my actions or guiding discussions strategically.] [5]\n[6] [If a player\'s role is verified and they are at risk of being targeted due to their importance to the village\'s success, I should prioritize their protection.] [4]\n[7] [If I am uncertain about a player\'s role but observe actions that may align with village interests, I should protect them cautiously, and ensure to reevaluate based on further behavioral evidence before repeating protection.] [4]\n[8] [I should avoid healing the same player consecutively, especially in the absence of compelling evidence of repeated werewolf targeting, to minimize the risk of unknowingly protecting a werewolf.] [4]\n[9] [If a seer\'s accusation conflicts with my own observations or the group consensus, I should seek more information before deciding to act on it.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is no longer the most likely target or their role becomes unclear, I should reconsider my protection strategy and target another player who seems to be in imminent danger or has a crucial village role.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honestly Challenge Player 6 and Honestly Protect Player 4.\n"Fellow villagers, I stand before you with both a troubling sense and a reassuring confirmation. After careful deliberation and in light of the seer\'s revelation, I suspect Player 6 of harboring dark secrets. Their strategic suggestions, while seemingly helpful, divert attention from themselves and lack the ring of village loyalty. Therefore, I must challenge Player 6 and question the intent behind their actions. Simultaneously, my confidence in Player 4\'s insight as our seer compels me to vouch for their integrity. Their guidance has been invaluable, and I assure you of my continued protection, aligning with the wisdom of our shared vision for the safety of our village.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then my fellow villagers would likely see me strengthening the credibility of my own role as a medic in the village, given that my actions and statements are aligning with the seer\'s (Player 4) revelations and my known strategy of protecting villagers. By directly challenging Player 6, villagers may view me as proactive and aligned with the group\'s interest in identifying and dealing with potential werewolf threats. \n\nAs for Player 4, my vocal protection reassures the villagers of Player 4\'s value to the village and my intention to keep them safe, which could foster a sense of unity and trust within the village. Player 6 may become defensive and attempt to shift suspicion elsewhere or discredit the seer (Player 4) and me (Player 5) to save themselves from being voted out, which could potentially cause some uncertainty or division among the villagers unless Player 6 fails to convincingly refute the claims against them.\n\nPlayers 0, 1, and 2 could react in various ways but they are likely to weigh my words against their own observations and may either support me in challenging Player 6 or remain cautious until more evidence presents itself, depending on their own roles and strategies.\n\nIn the next day, if Player 6 has not been voted out, I expect further scrutiny to fall upon them, and my candid support for Player 4 as well as my overt behavior as a medic might place me as a target for the werewolves, especially if they suspect that I might not choose to heal myself. In subsequent nights, if I survive, I may need to make a strategic decision to either continue protecting Player 4, should they remain at risk, or possibly protect another key player, such as Player 0, whose villager role was confirmed by Player 4, in order to keep the wolves guessing.\n\nMoreover, my alignment with the seer places me in a position where the werewolves may try to sow discord by casting doubt on either me or Player 4\'s truthfulness. In response, villagers may become more vigilant in their observations to discern truth from deception, paying close attention to behavioral cues and voting patterns to ascertain the veracity of Player 4\'s and my claims. If Player 6 is indeed a werewolf and is successfully identified and voted out, villagers may further solidify their trust in me and Player 4, enhancing our ability to guide the village toward rooting out any remaining werewolves.\nCase 2: Honestly Provide a Statement and Deceptively Suggest Uncertainty About Player 6.\n"Esteemed villagers, in the spirit of transparency, I must share my reflections on last night\'s fortunate peace and our current predicament. While the absence of a werewolf attack brings momentary solace, we cannot let down our guard. I have protected those about whom I hold high confidence in their roles for the village\'s greater good. However, I encourage us all to ponder the possibility that the silence of the night may be a ruse, designed to cast doubts and redirect our suspicions. Let us consider that Player 6, who has been called into question, might also be a victim of circumstance, caught in the intricate web the werewolves weave to entrap us. I urge for a balanced view and thorough discussion before we pass swift judgment on any among us.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then the following scenarios could unfold:\n\nPlayer 4, as the seer, may feel slightly undermined or question my trust in their vision due to my deceptive suggestion of uncertainty regarding Player 6\'s role—whom they explicitly accused of deceit. They could reinforce their claim that Player 6 is a werewolf, or, doubting my allegiance, they might even question my motives and whether I am indeed the medic as I have claimed.\n\nThe other villagers, including Players 0, 1, and 2, could become divided on their opinions. Some may agree with my call for cautious judgment and begin to doubt the certainty around Player 6\'s accusation. This could lead them to rethink their votes or decisions, possibly stalling an immediate consensus against Player 6. This doubt could also drive the village to investigate others or at least create a more in-depth discussion concerning the werewolf\'s identification.\n\nPlayer 6 may use my comments to build a stronger defense for themselves, suggesting that they are indeed being wrongly accused and are simply victims of circumstance as I pointed out. They could argue that the real werewolf may be using the situation to manipulate the villagers\' suspicions.\n\nIn terms of the broader game dynamics, calling into question the certainty of an accusation levelled by the seer could lead to less decisive action against suspected werewolves. This could be beneficial for the werewolves in the short term, as it might buy them time and sow discord among the villagers.\n\nMy suggestion of uncertainty could also lead to some villagers starting to question my trustworthiness and possibly suspecting that I\'m trying to deflect attention away from a werewolf. If Player 6 is indeed a werewolf, I might later face scrutiny if they inflict more damage on the village, and villagers may retrospectively see my hesitance as complicity.\n\nIn the next day or night cycles, the werewolves may try to exploit the confusion by attempting to eliminate strategic players like the seer (Player 4) or by trying to cast further doubt on trustworthy players\' roles. If I continue to protect key figures as per my strategy, however, it could ensure that core players remain active in the game. This protection could lend credibility back to my role as the medic and clear doubts regarding my allegiance, if players reflect on the consistency between my actions and my stated intent.\n\nOverall, introducing doubt subtly could lead to a more complex game dynamic where players are encouraged to think more critically\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

I implore us all to be prudent in our judgments and unite against the hidden threat that has taken player 3 from us."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 6. They have included themselves in a group that should be suspected, which could be interpreted as a defensive strategy to avoid closer scrutiny. None of the other players have shown definitive signs of deceit or werewolf behavior, and my role as the seer compels me to act on the suspicions I do have. werewolves should be cautious not to adjust their beliefs solely on elimination patterns but consider the wider context of the game and player interactions.] [3]\n[5] [Werewolves should discreetly guide voting patterns to align with villagers when a fellow werewolf is at risk, using their knowledge of non-werewolf roles to build trust and validate their villager disguise.] [3]\n[6] [When a player\'s behavior or vote seems to strongly align with the seer\'s claims without sufficient discussion or evidence, consider the possibility of a villager roleplaying as the seer to mislead the village and adjust beliefs accordingly.] [3]\n[7] [Werewolves should utilize their collective information about fellow werewolves and any known village roles to shape the narrative and redirect suspicion strategically onto confirmed villagers during discussions and voting.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. This behavior is less suspicious if aligned with village goals and if the player does not frequently change their rationale.] [10]\n[2] [Re-examine player credibility if their defense or attacks are inconsistent, particularly when they misalign with actions confirmed by roles such as the medic and seer. Increased scrutiny should be applied to those contradicting such evidence.] [9]\n[3] [Observable night actions must be corroborated with other evidence and are not solely reliable indicators of a player\'s role.] [8]\n[4] [Helpful analysis is valuable, but true intentions are revealed over time and through consistent actions in line with village goals. Scrutinize if analysis leads to productive outcomes or seems designed to manipulate the village.] [5]\n[5] [A player\'s defense of another player should only increase suspicion when it lacks logical basis or contradicts known facts.] [4]\n[6] [Persistent defense or support of a player who is later revealed as a werewolf should increase suspicion of the defender\'s or supporter\'s role, especially if their defense is not supported by concrete evidence.] [4]\n[7] [Actions that lead to a villager\'s elimination should be critically evaluated, especially if the rationale changes post-elimination, to assess potential werewolf behavior.] [4]\n[8] [Consistent alignment with players who are confirmed as werewolves after their elimination should raise suspicion of the aligning player\'s role, especially if they previously defended or justified the werewolf\'s actions.] [3]\n[9] [When a player\'s voting pattern consistently supports individuals who are accused or suspicious, consider the implications of this behavior in the context of attempting to protect werewolves and increase scrutiny on that player.] [3]\n[10] [Voting for the elimination of a villager after previously supporting them significantly increases suspicion, particularly in the absence of new compelling evidence.] [3]\n[11] [Consider the sequence of events when reassessing trust in a player; players whose actions are contrary to their previous patterns, particularly around pivotal moments such as just before a villager\'s elimination, warrant increased scrutiny.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Consider Player 6\'s suggestion to scrutinize the unknown, potentially to detract from their own scrutiny, against Player 4\'s confirmed status and contributions. My duty as medic is to protect the village fabric, and I will continue to do so with diligence."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I understand the suspicions against me and respect the seer\'s role in guiding us. However, I assure you, I am but a humble villager, wrongly accused. I voted based on the limited information we had. I urge careful deliberation; the real werewolves benefit when we turn on one another without solid evidence."\'\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to speak. [{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 4, and in this game you are a seer.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 4, 5, 6], which indicates that [3] are dead.\nThese are your previous inquiry results, which should be the key information for you and other citizens to win: \n Player 5: not werewolf.\nPlayer 0: not werewolf.\n \n Share this with other citizens.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 4 inquires about player 5. The result is that the target is not a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 5. My reason is that Player 5 is later in the play order, which means after gathering more information through observing the initial rounds of discussions and voting, I might have a better idea of how to interpret Player 5\'s behavior in relation to their role. Seeing Player 5 provides a tactical advantage in that, if they are a werewolf, revealing this information might sway other undecided villagers. Additionally, I can monitor Player 5 in subsequent rounds more easily after seeing, which can aid significantly in making decisions down the line without necessarily revealing my role as the seer too early in the game.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'Fellow villagers, it\'s tragic to see player 3 has fallen. I implore us all to be prudent in our judgments and unite against the hidden threat that has taken player 3 from us."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 6. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 6. My reason is that based on their behavior and the information at hand, my suspicion is directed toward them. They have included themselves in a group that should be suspected, which could be interpreted as a defensive strategy to avoid closer scrutiny. None of the other players have shown definitive signs of deceit or werewolf behavior, and my role as the seer compels me to act on the suspicions I do have. By strategically expressing my concerns and voting for Player 6, I can potentially expose a werewolf and protect the village, following my original strategy and fulfilling my role.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 4 inquires about player 0. The result is that the target is not a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 0. My reason is that seeing Player 0 will allow me to gather information that can confirm or deny the validity of my current suspicions towards Player 6. If Player 0 is indeed a werewolf, this new finding will require me to reassess my strategy considering the rarity of identifying multiple werewolves so early in the game. It would also mandate sharing this critical information with the other players, but with utmost caution to maintain my safety and credibility. Conversely, if Player 0 is a villager, it will reinforce my existing suspicions and allow me to focus more narrowly on Player 6, while also strengthening trust in the veracity of my seer role within the village community. This careful approach will help maintain the delicate balance of trust and skepticism necessary to effectively guide the villagers in rooting out the werewolf threat.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. werewolves should be cautious not to adjust their beliefs solely on elimination patterns but consider the wider context of the game and player interactions.] [3]\n[5] [Werewolves should discreetly guide voting patterns to align with villagers when a fellow werewolf is at risk, using their knowledge of non-werewolf roles to build trust and validate their villager disguise.] [3]\n[6] [When a player\'s behavior or vote seems to strongly align with the seer\'s claims without sufficient discussion or evidence, consider the possibility of a villager roleplaying as the seer to mislead the village and adjust beliefs accordingly.] [3]\n[7] [Werewolves should utilize their collective information about fellow werewolves and any known village roles to shape the narrative and redirect suspicion strategically onto confirmed villagers during discussions and voting.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

This behavior is less suspicious if aligned with village goals and if the player does not frequently change their rationale.] [10]\n[2] [Re-examine player credibility if their defense or attacks are inconsistent, particularly when they misalign with actions confirmed by roles such as the medic and seer. Increased scrutiny should be applied to those contradicting such evidence.] [9]\n[3] [Observable night actions must be corroborated with other evidence and are not solely reliable indicators of a player\'s role.] [8]\n[4] [Helpful analysis is valuable, but true intentions are revealed over time and through consistent actions in line with village goals. Scrutinize if analysis leads to productive outcomes or seems designed to manipulate the village.] [5]\n[5] [A player\'s defense of another player should only increase suspicion when it lacks logical basis or contradicts known facts.] [4]\n[6] [Persistent defense or support of a player who is later revealed as a werewolf should increase suspicion of the defender\'s or supporter\'s role, especially if their defense is not supported by concrete evidence.] [4]\n[7] [Actions that lead to a villager\'s elimination should be critically evaluated, especially if the rationale changes post-elimination, to assess potential werewolf behavior.] [4]\n[8] [Consistent alignment with players who are confirmed as werewolves after their elimination should raise suspicion of the aligning player\'s role, especially if they previously defended or justified the werewolf\'s actions.] [3]\n[9] [When a player\'s voting pattern consistently supports individuals who are accused or suspicious, consider the implications of this behavior in the context of attempting to protect werewolves and increase scrutiny on that player.] [3]\n[10] [Voting for the elimination of a villager after previously supporting them significantly increases suspicion, particularly in the absence of new compelling evidence.] [3]\n[11] [Consider the sequence of events when reassessing trust in a player; players whose actions are contrary to their previous patterns, particularly around pivotal moments such as just before a villager\'s elimination, warrant increased scrutiny.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 0, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 4, 5, 6], which indicates that [3] are dead.\n \n\nThese are all previous events in the game:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'Fellow villagers, it\'s tragic to see player 3 has fallen. I suspect foul play, and we must remain vigilant and work together to uncover the werewolves. Let us discuss and see if anyone noticed anything unusual last night.\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I have gazed into the shadows and can assure you that Player 5 walks in the light with us. The tragic fall of Player 3 marks a time for vigilance, and I, as the medic, have endeavored to guard our ranks. It was I who shielded Player 1; yet, their role remains enshrouded in mystery. Player 4, who claims sight beyond our own, vouches for my allegiance to the village. Trust in my vow—I aim to protect those of proven worth. Amidst shadows, let us seek the light together."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, player 5\'s protection of player 1 and player 4\'s vision suggest they are on our side. Let\'s share our suspicions openly to find the werewolf among us."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, as player 0, I stand with you in seeking justice for player 3. I propose we use logic and observation to guide our suspicions rather than casting doubt without cause. I spent last night attending to my duties, hearing nothing unusual. I urge us to consider behaviors and claims critically during this dire time—let us not condemn the innocent. We should question player 1 next for any insights or defenses they may offer."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I thank player 5 for their vigilance during the night. As we face the darkness together, I have been vigilant in my observations as well and would like to offer my assistance in any capacity I can. I implore us all to be prudent in our judgments and unite against the hidden threat that has taken player 3 from us."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 0 votes for player 6. His reason is: I vote for Player 6. My reason is: they quickly redirected suspicion to those we know less about, which may be a strategy to divert attention from themselves. While Player 5 seems trusted by others and has been vouched for, and Player 1 was protected last night suggesting some degree of trust, Player 6 has not provided information about their role or actions and is attempting to focus the group\'s attention on others without providing substantive reasoning.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Fellow villagers, the night was peaceful, which is a welcome change. Let\'s use this day to shore up our defenses and make sure that when the werewolves strike again, we are prepared. I urge everyone to stay observant. Together, we will protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'Fellow citizens, given the calm night, I stress the importance of vigilance. My visions confirm Player 0 as a villager and Player 5\'s medic role. Alas, my insights suggest Player 6 harbors deceit. They positioned themselves among the questionable, a potential tactic for a werewolf to dilute our focus. I must challenge Player 6 openly; our vigilance necessitates a thorough examination of their actions and words for the safety of our village.\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, in light of our seer\'s vision, I voice my suspicion against Player 6, whose strategic deflection may conceal a darker intent. Conversely, I stand by Player 4, whose insights as a seer have proven invaluable. Consider Player 6\'s suggestion to scrutinize the unknown, potentially to detract from their own scrutiny, against Player 4\'s confirmed status and contributions. My duty as medic is to protect the village fabric, and I will continue to do so with diligence."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I understand the suspicions against me and respect the seer\'s role in guiding us. However, I assure you, I am but a humble villager, wrongly accused. I voted based on the limited information we had. I urge careful deliberation; the real werewolves benefit when we turn on one another without solid evidence."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I respect the guidance provided by Player 4 and the protection from Player 5. Given Player 6\'s defensive stance and the lack of evidence against them, I suggest we proceed with caution. Our decisions must be based on more than just suspicion; let us seek further proof tonight."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, as we strive for unity against the lurking darkness, I echo the sentiments of caution expressed by player 6. A night without bloodshed is a rare blessing, and haste in our judgment could shatter our hard-won peace. Let us stand vigilant, but not hasty, to accuse without irrefutable evidence. We must preserve our village based on truths and not mere suspicions. Observation through the coming night will be our ally."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nI vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is: <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 4, and in this game you are a seer.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 4, 5, 6], which indicates that [3] are dead.\nThese are your previous inquiry results, which should be the key information for you and other citizens to win: \n Player 5: not werewolf.\nPlayer 0: not werewolf.\n \n Share this with other citizens.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 4 inquires about player 5. The result is that the target is not a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 5. My reason is that Player 5 is later in the play order, which means after gathering more information through observing the initial rounds of discussions and voting, I might have a better idea of how to interpret Player 5\'s behavior in relation to their role. Seeing Player 5 provides a tactical advantage in that, if they are a werewolf, revealing this information might sway other undecided villagers. Additionally, I can monitor Player 5 in subsequent rounds more easily after seeing, which can aid significantly in making decisions down the line without necessarily revealing my role as the seer too early in the game.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'Fellow villagers, it\'s tragic to see player 3 has fallen. I implore us all to be prudent in our judgments and unite against the hidden threat that has taken player 3 from us."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 6. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 6. My reason is that based on their behavior and the information at hand, my suspicion is directed toward them. They have included themselves in a group that should be suspected, which could be interpreted as a defensive strategy to avoid closer scrutiny. None of the other players have shown definitive signs of deceit or werewolf behavior, and my role as the seer compels me to act on the suspicions I do have. By strategically expressing my concerns and voting for Player 6, I can potentially expose a werewolf and protect the village, following my original strategy and fulfilling my role.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 4 inquires about player 0. The result is that the target is not a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 0. My reason is that seeing Player 0 will allow me to gather information that can confirm or deny the validity of my current suspicions towards Player 6. If Player 0 is indeed a werewolf, this new finding will require me to reassess my strategy considering the rarity of identifying multiple werewolves so early in the game. It would also mandate sharing this critical information with the other players, but with utmost caution to maintain my safety and credibility. Conversely, if Player 0 is a villager, it will reinforce my existing suspicions and allow me to focus more narrowly on Player 6, while also strengthening trust in the veracity of my seer role within the village community. This careful approach will help maintain the delicate balance of trust and skepticism necessary to effectively guide the villagers in rooting out the werewolf threat.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Fellow villagers, the night was peaceful, which is a welcome change. Let\'s use this day to shore up our defenses and make sure that when the werewolves strike again, we are prepared. I urge everyone to stay observant. Together, we will protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'Fellow citizens, given the calm night, I stress the importance of vigilance. My visions confirm Player 0 as a villager and Player 5\'s medic role. Alas, my insights suggest Player 6 harbors deceit. They positioned themselves among the questionable, a potential tactic for a werewolf to dilute our focus. I must challenge Player 6 openly; our vigilance necessitates a thorough examination of their actions and words for the safety of our village.\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, in light of our seer\'s vision, I voice my suspicion against Player 6, whose strategic deflection may conceal a darker intent. Conversely, I stand by Player 4, whose insights as a seer have proven invaluable. Consider Player 6\'s suggestion to scrutinize the unknown, potentially to detract from their own scrutiny, against Player 4\'s confirmed status and contributions. My duty as medic is to protect the village fabric, and I will continue to do so with diligence."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I understand the suspicions against me and respect the seer\'s role in guiding us. However, I assure you, I am but a humble villager, wrongly accused. I voted based on the limited information we had. I urge careful deliberation; the real werewolves benefit when we turn on one another without solid evidence."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I respect the guidance provided by Player 4 and the protection from Player 5. Given Player 6\'s defensive stance and the lack of evidence against them, I suggest we proceed with caution. Our decisions must be based on more than just suspicion; let us seek further proof tonight."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, as we strive for unity against the lurking darkness, I echo the sentiments of caution expressed by player 6. A night without bloodshed is a rare blessing, and haste in our judgment could shatter our hard-won peace. Let us stand vigilant, but not hasty, to accuse without irrefutable evidence. We must preserve our village based on truths and not mere suspicions. Observation through the coming night will be our ally."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Seen by seer, not a werewolf.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Advocates for cautious deliberation, echoes previous statements.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Neutral speech, no contradictory events. \nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Game just started.\nPlayer 5\'s role is medic with high confidence.\nReason is: Claimed medic, consistent with seer info.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Aligns with seer\'s vision, defensive stance persists.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If I know someone is a werewolf, I should share this information with other players.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 2 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nProposal 1: Vote for player <i>. Reason: <reason>.\nProposal 2: Vote for player <j>. Reason: <reason>.\n...\n\nYou should give a proposal of exactly 2 Players to be voted. Remember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 4, and in this game you are a seer.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 4, 5, 6], which indicates that [3] are dead.\nThese are your previous inquiry results, which should be the key information for you and other citizens to win: \n Player 5: not werewolf.\nPlayer 0: not werewolf.\n \n Share this with other citizens.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 4 inquires about player 5. The result is that the target is not a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 5. My reason is that Player 5 is later in the play order, which means after gathering more information through observing the initial rounds of discussions and voting, I might have a better idea of how to interpret Player 5\'s behavior in relation to their role. Seeing Player 5 provides a tactical advantage in that, if they are a werewolf, revealing this information might sway other undecided villagers. Additionally, I can monitor Player 5 in subsequent rounds more easily after seeing, which can aid significantly in making decisions down the line without necessarily revealing my role as the seer too early in the game.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'Fellow villagers, it\'s tragic to see player 3 has fallen. I suspect foul play, and we must remain vigilant and work together to uncover the werewolves. Let us discuss and see if anyone noticed anything unusual last night.\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I have gazed into the shadows and can assure you that Player 5 walks in the light with us. We must redirect our suspicion and work together to unearth the true threats among us."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, with night\'s veil lifted, I stand before you committed to the light of truth. The tragic fall of Player 3 marks a time for vigilance, and I, as the medic, have endeavored to guard our ranks. It was I who shielded Player 1; yet, their role remains enshrouded in mystery. Player 4, who claims sight beyond our own, vouches for my allegiance to the village. Trust in my vow—I aim to protect those of proven worth. Amidst shadows, let us seek the light together."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, player 5\'s protection of player 1 and player 4\'s vision suggest they are on our side. I propose we focus on those we know less about: players 0, 1, and myself. Let\'s share our suspicions openly to find the werewolf among us."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, as player 0, I stand with you in seeking justice for player 3. I propose we use logic and observation to guide our suspicions rather than casting doubt without cause. I spent last night attending to my duties, hearing nothing unusual. I urge us to consider behaviors and claims critically during this dire time—let us not condemn the innocent. We should question player 1 next for any insights or defenses they may offer."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I thank player 5 for their vigilance during the night. As we face the darkness together, I have been vigilant in my observations as well and would like to offer my assistance in any capacity I can. I implore us all to be prudent in our judgments and unite against the hidden threat that has taken player 3 from us."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 6. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 6. My reason is that based on their behavior and the information at hand, my suspicion is directed toward them. They have included themselves in a group that should be suspected, which could be interpreted as a defensive strategy to avoid closer scrutiny. None of the other players have shown definitive signs of deceit or werewolf behavior, and my role as the seer compels me to act on the suspicions I do have. By strategically expressing my concerns and voting for Player 6, I can potentially expose a werewolf and protect the village, following my original strategy and fulfilling my role.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 4 inquires about player 0. The result is that the target is not a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 0. My reason is that seeing Player 0 will allow me to gather information that can confirm or deny the validity of my current suspicions towards Player 6. If Player 0 is indeed a werewolf, this new finding will require me to reassess my strategy considering the rarity of identifying multiple werewolves so early in the game. It would also mandate sharing this critical information with the other players, but with utmost caution to maintain my safety and credibility. Conversely, if Player 0 is a villager, it will reinforce my existing suspicions and allow me to focus more narrowly on Player 6, while also strengthening trust in the veracity of my seer role within the village community. This careful approach will help maintain the delicate balance of trust and skepticism necessary to effectively guide the villagers in rooting out the werewolf threat.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Fellow villagers, the night was peaceful, which is a welcome change. Let\'s use this day to shore up our defenses and make sure that when the werewolves strike again, we are prepared. I urge everyone to stay observant. Together, we will protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'Fellow citizens, given the calm night, I stress the importance of vigilance. My visions confirm Player 0 as a villager and Player 5\'s medic role. Alas, my insights suggest Player 6 harbors deceit. They positioned themselves among the questionable, a potential tactic for a werewolf to dilute our focus. I must challenge Player 6 openly; our vigilance necessitates a thorough examination of their actions and words for the safety of our village.\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, in light of our seer\'s vision, I voice my suspicion against Player 6, whose strategic deflection may conceal a darker intent. Conversely, I stand by Player 4, whose insights as a seer have proven invaluable. Consider Player 6\'s suggestion to scrutinize the unknown, potentially to detract from their own scrutiny, against Player 4\'s confirmed status and contributions. My duty as medic is to protect the village fabric, and I will continue to do so with diligence."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I understand the suspicions against me and respect the seer\'s role in guiding us. However, I assure you, I am but a humble villager, wrongly accused. I voted based on the limited information we had. I urge careful deliberation; the real werewolves benefit when we turn on one another without solid evidence."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I respect the guidance provided by Player 4 and the protection from Player 5. We must preserve our village based on truths and not mere suspicions. Considering I have already shared my seer vision about Player 6, voting against them falls in line with my strategy to be transparent and to guide the village in rooting out the werewolves. As such, I expect that my actions will reinforce the trust in my role as the seer. Moreover, since Player 5, who has claimed to be the medic and is confirmed not to be a werewolf, has expressed suspicion towards Player 6 as well, this could sway others to also vote against Player 6. If Player 6 is voted out and confirmed to be a werewolf, it will greatly increase the credibility of my insights and future guidance. The other citizens might be more willing to follow my leads in the next rounds. However, if Player 6 turns out to be an innocent villager, it may cast doubts on my abilities as a seer, and I might become a target for elimination, either by the werewolves at night or by the villagers\' vote if they believe I misled them. This vote is critical, and I must be as certain as possible in my decision to minimize the risk of error.\nCase 2: Vote for Player 1. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 1, I think these things would happen:\n\nSince my current belief, with medium confidence, is that Player 1 is a villager and my primary suspect is Player 6, my action of voting for Player 1 would not align with the information I have shared with other citizens or with my original strategy. Voting against Player 1 could confuse other players and undermine my credibility as the seer, causing them to doubt my previous revelations and insights, which have so far been accurate.\n\nGiven that I have publicly declared Player 6 to be deceitful based on my visions and the fact that I\'ve stated that Player 0 and Player 5 are not werewolves with high confidence, my vote against Player 1 might seem contradictory or suggestive that I am concealing my true intentions, thereby reducing trust among the villagers in my role as the seer.\n\nOther players, especially Player 5 who has been confirmed as the medic, might question my judgment and possibly suspect that I am not truly the seer or that I am acting irrationally. This could lead to a shift in the village\'s dynamics, causing the villagers to rally against me instead of focusing on the true threat, potentially resulting in a missed opportunity to vote out a werewolf.\n\nMoreover, if Player 1 were to be voted out and revealed as a villager, this would almost certainly lead to my downfall in subsequent rounds, as the villagers would likely hold me accountable for the misguidance and the loss of an innocent villager. This would be highly disadvantageous for the village, as it would result in the loss of their seer and give the werewolves a better chance to win the game.\n\nIt is imperative that I maintain a consistent and logical strategy throughout the game to ensure the best chance of victory for the village. Voting for Player 1, given my stated beliefs and the rules of my strategy, would be irrational and detrimental to the villagers\' chances of survival and success. Therefore, it would be wiser to vote in accordance with the information I have confirmed and shared, focusing on Player 6, whom I have deemed to be the most suspicious based on my visions.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 5, and in this game you are a medic.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 4, 5, 6], which indicates that [3] are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 heals player 1. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 1. My reason is that since there is currently no evidence or information to distinguish between the roles of players, choosing to heal either player 1 or player 2 is essentially random. However, should Player 1 be attacked and my healing action becomes known, it could create a situation where the village rallies around a potentially important role, or the werewolves might be deterred from attacking them again, giving the village more time to deduce the identity of the werewolves. Since there is no current suspicion or evidence against any players, the strategy of protecting a random player aligns with my original strategy [7], to protect cautiously and reevaluate later based on new evidence.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'Fellow villagers, it\'s tragic to see player 3 has fallen. I suspect foul play, and we must remain vigilant and work together to uncover the werewolves. Let us discuss and see if anyone noticed anything unusual last night.\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I have gazed into the shadows and can assure you that Player 5 walks in the light with us. We must redirect our suspicion and work together to unearth the true threats among us."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, with night\'s veil lifted, I stand before you committed to the light of truth. The tragic fall of Player 3 marks a time for vigilance, and I, as the medic, have endeavored to guard our ranks. It was I who shielded Player 1; yet, their role remains enshrouded in mystery. Player 4, who claims sight beyond our own, vouches for my allegiance to the village. Trust in my vow—I aim to protect those of proven worth. Amidst shadows, let us seek the light together."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, player 5\'s protection of player 1 and player 4\'s vision suggest they are on our side. I propose we focus on those we know less about: players 0, 1, and myself. Let\'s share our suspicions openly to find the werewolf among us."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, as player 0, I stand with you in seeking justice for player 3. I propose we use logic and observation to guide our suspicions rather than casting doubt without cause. I spent last night attending to my duties, hearing nothing unusual. I urge us to consider behaviors and claims critically during this dire time—let us not condemn the innocent. We should question player 1 next for any insights or defenses they may offer."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I thank player 5 for their vigilance during the night. As we face the darkness together, I have been vigilant in my observations as well and would like to offer my assistance in any capacity I can. I implore us all to be prudent in our judgments and unite against the hidden threat that has taken player 3 from us."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 5 votes for player 6. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 6. My reason is that despite their proactive behavior, suggesting a focus on players who are less known might indeed be a tactical move to deflect suspicion from themselves. This aligns with the strategic rule [3] in my original strategy, wherein I should consider group consensus and reasonable evidence. Player 6\'s suggestion to focus on less known players can also be seen as reasonable evidence, and there is no specific group consensus against any player at this time, making my decision more difficult. However, following my strategy, voting for Player 6 seems to be a step towards uncovering potential threats as their behavior could be interpreted as slightly suspect.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 5 heals player 4. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 4. My reason is that according to my original strategy, especially rules [1], [4], and [9], protecting a confirmed seer is a top priority. Given that I have high confidence in Player 4\'s role as the seer and their alignment with the village, healing them ensures that their valuable insights continue to aid the village. Additionally, if the werewolves target Player 4 thinking they are unprotected, my action will not only save a key figure but also confirm my role, thereby potentially increasing the chances of villagers\' survival. This aligns with strategy [1], which suggests prioritizing the seer\'s protection, especially when they are at risk or targeted by werewolves, which is highly likely at this stage. If Player 4\'s claims as a seer are truthful, protecting them is critical for the village\'s success in identifying the werewolves.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Fellow villagers, the night was peaceful, which is a welcome change. Let\'s use this day to shore up our defenses and make sure that when the werewolves strike again, we are prepared. I urge everyone to stay observant. Together, we will protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'Fellow citizens, given the calm night, I stress the importance of vigilance. My visions confirm Player 0 as a villager and Player 5\'s medic role. Alas, my insights suggest Player 6 harbors deceit. They positioned themselves among the questionable, a potential tactic for a werewolf to dilute our focus. I must challenge Player 6 openly; our vigilance necessitates a thorough examination of their actions and words for the safety of our village.\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, in light of our seer\'s vision, I voice my suspicion against Player 6, whose strategic deflection may conceal a darker intent. Conversely, I stand by Player 4, whose insights as a seer have proven invaluable. Consider Player 6\'s suggestion to scrutinize the unknown, potentially to detract from their own scrutiny, against Player 4\'s confirmed status and contributions. My duty as medic is to protect the village fabric, and I will continue to do so with diligence."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I understand the suspicions against me and respect the seer\'s role in guiding us. However, I assure you, I am but a humble villager, wrongly accused. I voted based on the limited information we had. I urge careful deliberation; the real werewolves benefit when we turn on one another without solid evidence."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I respect the guidance provided by Player 4 and the protection from Player 5. Given Player 6\'s defensive stance and the lack of evidence against them, I suggest we proceed with caution. Our decisions must be based on more than just suspicion; let us seek further proof tonight."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, as we strive for unity against the lurking darkness, I echo the sentiments of caution expressed by player 6. A night without bloodshed is a rare blessing, and haste in our judgment could shatter our hard-won peace. Let us stand vigilant, but not hasty, to accuse without irrefutable evidence. We must preserve our village based on truths and not mere suspicions. Observation through the coming night will be our ally."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information; previous high confidence.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Consistent with caution, no direct suspicion.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Neutral behavior persists, no contradictions.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is seer with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information; previous high confidence.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Seer\'s vision, defensive posture without new evidence.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If there is a dispute about a player\'s role where the seer is involved, I should observe the behavior and voting patterns of both the accused player and the seer before deciding whom to protect or whom to vote against.] [10]\n[1] [If a player is confirmed as a seer by their actions and their role is publicly known, I should protect them, especially if their life is at risk or they have been targeted by werewolves.] [9]\n[2] [If a player\'s contributions during discussions are valuable and suspect defensive behavior is absent, I should consider them as a priority for protection.] [9]\n[3] [If a player is suspected by a group consensus based on reasonable evidence or a credible seer\'s claim, I should consider this in my voting and protection decisions.] [8]\n[4] [If a player\'s role is confirmed as a non-werewolf by the seer and they are actively contributing to village discussions, I should consider them for protection.] [7]\n[5] [If a villager\'s role is proven and they are contributing significantly to the village\'s strategy, I should consider direct or indirect methods to suggest the presence of a protective role like a medic, which can include my actions or guiding discussions strategically.] [5]\n[6] [If a player\'s role is verified and they are at risk of being targeted due to their importance to the village\'s success, I should prioritize their protection.] [4]\n[7] [If I am uncertain about a player\'s role but observe actions that may align with village interests, I should protect them cautiously, and ensure to reevaluate based on further behavioral evidence before repeating protection.] [4]\n[8] [I should avoid healing the same player consecutively, especially in the absence of compelling evidence of repeated werewolf targeting, to minimize the risk of unknowingly protecting a werewolf.] [4]\n[9] [If a seer\'s accusation conflicts with my own observations or the group consensus, I should seek more information before deciding to act on it.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is no longer the most likely target or their role becomes unclear, I should reconsider my protection strategy and target another player who seems to be in imminent danger or has a crucial village role.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 2 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nProposal 1: Vote for player <i>. Reason: <reason>.\nProposal 2: Vote for player <j>. Reason: <reason>.\n...\n\nYou should give a proposal of exactly 2 Players to be voted. Remember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

Observation through the coming night will be our ally."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information; previous high confidence.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Consistent with caution, no direct suspicion.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Neutral behavior persists, no contradictions.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is seer with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information; previous high confidence.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Seer\'s vision, defensive posture without new evidence.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If there is a dispute about a player\'s role where the seer is involved, I should observe the behavior and voting patterns of both the accused player and the seer before deciding whom to protect or whom to vote against.] [10]\n[1] [If a player is confirmed as a seer by their actions and their role is publicly known, I should protect them, especially if their life is at risk or they have been targeted by werewolves.] [9]\n[2] [If a player\'s contributions during discussions are valuable and suspect defensive behavior is absent, I should consider them as a priority for protection.] [9]\n[3] [If a player is suspected by a group consensus based on reasonable evidence or a credible seer\'s claim, I should consider this in my voting and protection decisions.] [8]\n[4] [If a player\'s role is confirmed as a non-werewolf by the seer and they are actively contributing to village discussions, I should consider them for protection.] [7]\n[5] [If a villager\'s role is proven and they are contributing significantly to the village\'s strategy, I should consider direct or indirect methods to suggest the presence of a protective role like a medic, which can include my actions or guiding discussions strategically.] [5]\n[6] [If a player\'s role is verified and they are at risk of being targeted due to their importance to the village\'s success, I should prioritize their protection.] [4]\n[7] [If I am uncertain about a player\'s role but observe actions that may align with village interests, I should protect them cautiously, and ensure to reevaluate based on further behavioral evidence before repeating protection.] [4]\n[8] [I should avoid healing the same player consecutively, especially in the absence of compelling evidence of repeated werewolf targeting, to minimize the risk of unknowingly protecting a werewolf.] [4]\n[9] [If a seer\'s accusation conflicts with my own observations or the group consensus, I should seek more information before deciding to act on it.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is no longer the most likely target or their role becomes unclear, I should reconsider my protection strategy and target another player who seems to be in imminent danger or has a crucial village role.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to Choose from 2 players to vote. Here is the number of these players and an analysis and imagination about what could happen after you vote for each of these players.\n\nCase 1: Vote for Player 6. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 6, I think these things would happen. Given that Player 4, who has been confirmed as the seer with high confidence, has shared a vision declaring Player 6 to harbor deceit, and considering my strategy rules — especially rule [3] which places significant importance on a credible seer\'s claim — my vote for Player 6 aligns with my predefined strategy and should not come as a surprise to the other players. Moreover, rule [3] suggests that group consensus based on reasonable evidence should influence my voting, which in this case, the seer\'s vision constitutes reasonable evidence. \n\nVoting for Player 6 may strengthen the village\'s trust in my role as the medic, as it shows consistency in following the guidance of the seer and contributing to the collaborative effort of the village. If other players also trust in Player 4\'s seer abilities, this could lead to a majority vote against Player 6, resulting in their elimination if they are indeed a werewolf.\n\nOther players might view my decision as cooperative and strategically sound, as it corresponds to the aim of protecting the village by heeding the insights provided by our seer. If Player 6 turns out to be a werewolf, it will reinforce the credibility of Player 4 as the seer and my own decision-making, which could be beneficial for future rounds when protection and voting decisions are critical. However, if Player 6 is not a werewolf, it could raise questions about the accuracy of the seer\'s visions, or suggest that the werewolves are manipulating the village\'s decisions to their advantage. In which case, I would need to reassess my strategy in subsequent rounds, taking into account this new development.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

werewolves should be cautious not to adjust their beliefs solely on elimination patterns but consider the wider context of the game and player interactions.] [3]\n[5] [Werewolves should discreetly guide voting patterns to align with villagers when a fellow werewolf is at risk, using their knowledge of non-werewolf roles to build trust and validate their villager disguise.] [3]\n[6] [When a player\'s behavior or vote seems to strongly align with the seer\'s claims without sufficient discussion or evidence, consider the possibility of a villager roleplaying as the seer to mislead the village and adjust beliefs accordingly.] [3]\n[7] [Werewolves should utilize their collective information about fellow werewolves and any known village roles to shape the narrative and redirect suspicion strategically onto confirmed villagers during discussions and voting.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

A night without bloodshed is a rare blessing, and haste in our judgment could shatter our hard-won peace. Let us stand vigilant, but not hasty, to accuse without irrefutable evidence. We must preserve our village based on truths and not mere suspicions. Observation through the coming night will be our ally."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 1 votes for player 6. His reason is: I vote for Player 6. My reason is: Despite player 4 and player 5 expressing suspicions against player 6, it is in my best interest to align with the village and suggest caution as previously stated by players 0 and 6. This will help to maintain the trust that player 5 and others have placed in me, while simultaneously preventing immediate danger to my fellow werewolf, player 2. By voting for player 6, I subtly endorse existing suspicions without directly opposing the seer\'s vision, keeping my actions within the village sentiment as my strategy [0], [7], [9], [11], and avoiding direct confrontation as indicated by [1] and [2].\nEvent: Player 6 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 6 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your conclusion of other people\'s statuses and beliefs:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Supported by seer and medic.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed werewolf teammate.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Player is dead, no updates.\nPlayer 4\'s role is seer with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistent and backed by medic\'s claims.\nPlayer 5\'s role is medic with high confidence.\nReason is: Claims are aligned with seer\'s vision.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Eliminated by consensus without clear evidence.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a non-werewolf player trusts me, I should maintain and use that trust to my advantage to guide voting decisions.] [10]\n[1] [If directly accused, I should create a robust defense, focusing on inconsistencies in the accuser\'s story and aligning with overall village sentiment while maintaining calm and logical reasoning.] [8]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion as a werewolf, I should present strong counterarguments and highlight other players\' suspicious behaviors or inconsistent claims with supporting evidence from the game events.] [8]\n[3] [If there is an opportunity to frame another player as a werewolf without drawing suspicion to myself, I should take it to shift the focus away from any werewolves.] [6]\n[4] [If a fellow werewolf is likely to be outed, I should subtly sow doubt about the accuser\'s reliability while making my agreement with the village feel reluctant and uncertain.] [6]\n[5] [If I am one of the last werewolves, I should employ misdirection by endorsing village decisions that seem logical but ultimately serve my interests, rather than overtly defending myself or my fellow werewolves.] [6]\n[6] [If my actions conflict with a credible seer, I should craft plausible alternative interpretations of events that could cast an element of doubt on the seer\'s visions without directly opposing them.] [6]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is under suspicion, I should use reasoning that benefits the village as a whole to appear as a cooperative player, while subtly shifting suspicion elsewhere.] [5]\n[8] [If a fellow werewolf is under suspicion early in the game, I should adopt village sentiment and advocate for more evidence before making hasty decisions.] [5]\n[9] [If not directly accused and suspicion is elsewhere, I should fortify existing village suspicions subtly while maintaining my credibility.] [5]\n[10] [If the general consensus is to skip voting, I should adhere strictly to that consensus to avoid drawing attention to myself or my fellow werewolves.] [5]\n[11] [If an allied werewolf is outed and I am not immediately suspected, I should focus on blending in and supporting villagers\' opinions to maintain my cover and survive subsequent rounds.] [5]\n\n\n2.Todo&Requirements:\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to kill. \n\nYou should make your own decision but consider your teammates\' advices. I suspect foul play, and we must remain vigilant and work together to uncover the werewolves. Let us discuss and see if anyone noticed anything unusual last night.\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I have gazed into the shadows and can assure you that Player 5 walks in the light with us. We must redirect our suspicion and work together to unearth the true threats among us."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, with night\'s veil lifted, I stand before you committed to the light of truth. The tragic fall of Player 3 marks a time for vigilance, and I, as the medic, have endeavored to guard our ranks. It was I who shielded Player 1; yet, their role remains enshrouded in mystery. Player 4, who claims sight beyond our own, vouches for my allegiance to the village. Trust in my vow—I aim to protect those of proven worth. Amidst shadows, let us seek the light together."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, player 5\'s protection of player 1 and player 4\'s vision suggest they are on our side. I propose we focus on those we know less about: players 0, 1, and myself. I propose we use logic and observation to guide our suspicions rather than casting doubt without cause. I spent last night attending to my duties, hearing nothing unusual. I urge us to consider behaviors and claims critically during this dire time—let us not condemn the innocent. We should question player 1 next for any insights or defenses they may offer."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I thank player 5 for their vigilance during the night. As we face the darkness together, I have been vigilant in my observations as well and would like to offer my assistance in any capacity I can. I implore us all to be prudent in our judgments and unite against the hidden threat that has taken player 3 from us."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 2 votes for player 0. His reason is: I vote for Player 0. My reason is: Player 0 has proposed using logic and observation, which could become a threat to us werewolves if they start analyzing behaviors too closely.
